channel.title: Last Day - NEW & UPDATE
channel.description: All NEW and UPDATE articles from the last day with enhanced metadata

item.title: NEW: Urgent Patch for Critical WSUS Flaw as Attacks Surge
item.description:
Headline: Urgent Patch for Critical WSUS Flaw as Attacks Surge

Summary:
A critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in Microsoft's Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), tracked as CVE-2025-59287 with a CVSS score of 9.8, is being actively exploited by threat actors. The flaw allows unauthenticated attackers to achieve SYSTEM-level privileges, leading Microsoft to release an emergency out-of-band patch after its initial October fix proved insufficient. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating federal agencies to patch by November 14, 2025. Security researchers have observed in-the-wild attacks leveraging unsafe deserialization in the WSUS `GetCookie()` endpoint, underscoring the urgency for all organizations to apply the update immediately.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Meta Description: Urgent analysis of CVE-2025-59287, a critical RCE vulnerability in Microsoft WSUS being actively exploited. Learn detection methods and apply the emergency patch immediately.

Article Slug: critical-microsoft-wsus-flaw-cve-2025-59287-actively-exploited

Published Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Dublin Airport Breach Exposes 3.8 Million Passengers After Supplier Hack
item.description:
Headline: Dublin Airport Breach Exposes 3.8 Million Passengers After Supplier Hack

Summary:
Dublin Airport has confirmed a significant data breach impacting up to 3.8 million passengers who traveled in August 2025. The incident stemmed from a ransomware attack on a third-party IT supplier, Collins Aerospace, which provides check-in and boarding software. The Everest ransomware group has claimed responsibility, stating they stole 1.5 million passenger records and published them online. The exposed data includes full names, booking references, and contact information, putting millions of travelers at risk of sophisticated phishing and social engineering attacks. The breach is part of a wider attack on Collins Aerospace that disrupted several major European airports.

Severity: High

Categories: Data Breach, Supply Chain Attack, Ransomware

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: Details on the Dublin Airport data breach affecting 3.8 million passengers. The breach stemmed from a ransomware attack on third-party supplier Collins Aerospace.

Article Slug: dublin-airport-data-breach-august-2025-collins-aerospace

Published Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: DDoS Attack on Russian Food Agency Cripples National Supply Chains
item.description:
Headline: DDoS Attack on Russian Food Agency Cripples National Supply Chains

Summary:
Russia's federal agency for veterinary and phytosanitary surveillance, Rosselkhoznadzor, has been targeted by a large-scale distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack starting October 22, 2025. The attack crippled the agency's critical electronic certification systems, including the 'Mercury' platform, which is essential for tracking animal products. The outage caused significant delays in food shipments from major producers of meat, milk, and baby food across the nation, highlighting the vulnerability of critical national infrastructure to cyberattacks. Russian telecom providers are working to mitigate the attack, for which no group has claimed responsibility.

Severity: High

Categories: Cyberattack, Industrial Control Systems, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: A large-scale DDoS attack on Russia's food safety agency, Rosselkhoznadzor, has disrupted national food supply chains by taking critical certification systems offline.

Article Slug: ddos-attack-russian-food-safety-agency-disrupts-supply-chain

Published Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Safepay Ransomware Hits German Surveillance Firm Xortec, Sparking Supply Chain Fears
item.description:
Headline: Safepay Ransomware Hits German Surveillance Firm Xortec, Sparking Supply Chain Fears

Summary:
The Safepay ransomware group has claimed responsibility for a cyberattack against Xortec GmbH, a German provider of professional video surveillance solutions. The group has listed Xortec on its data leak site with a payment deadline of October 27, 2025. This attack raises significant supply chain concerns, as a compromise of a value-added distributor like Xortec could potentially lead to backdoored hardware or software being deployed in sensitive client environments. Safepay is a relatively new but aggressive ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation known for its rapid double-extortion attacks.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Supply Chain Attack, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: The Safepay ransomware group has targeted German video surveillance firm Xortec, raising concerns of a major supply chain attack with systemic risks.

Article Slug: safepay-ransomware-targets-german-video-surveillance-firm-xortec

Published Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Nations Sign Landmark UN Cybercrime Treaty Amidst Privacy and Rights Concerns
item.description:
Headline: Nations Sign Landmark UN Cybercrime Treaty Amidst Privacy and Rights Concerns

Summary:
In a landmark event in Hanoi, Vietnam, 72 nations have signed the first-ever United Nations Convention against Cybercrime. The treaty aims to establish a global legal framework for international cooperation in fighting digital crime, including provisions for rapid cross-border evidence sharing. While hailed by the UN as a major step in multilateralism, the convention has drawn sharp criticism from over 160 technology firms, including Meta and Dell, and various civil society groups. Critics warn its broad language could be used to criminalize legitimate security research and enable governments to repress dissent under the guise of fighting cybercrime.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Regulatory

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: Dozens of countries sign the first global UN Convention against Cybercrime in Hanoi. The treaty aims to foster international cooperation but faces criticism over privacy concerns.

Article Slug: un-cybercrime-treaty-signed-hanoi-amidst-privacy-concerns

Published Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Sun, 26 Oct 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →
